column4: Is there some quick way to reset Ubuntu, so everything is like after a fresh installation?
what told you to reboot?  Anyway, System->Preferences-Screen Resolution
I set my TV as second screen, and I was told to reboot
The screen resolution "window" doesn't do anything for me.
do you still have the TV plugged in?
No.
have you rebooted since unplugging the TV
Yes.
Have tried to change drivers, but no change.
have you clicked "detect displays"
Yes.
oh right.  what have you tried to change it to?
I'm not at that computer now, but I set it to some Ati Radeon thingie, because I found out that is what's inside the computer.
try  sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg -phigh  which will ask it to run the driver autodetection again
I did try that...
But, then my keyboard stopped working completely
So I guess I have to reinstall. But then I want to try something different...
try it without the '-phigh' and you will be given an option to confirm each step in the autodetction (such as selecting a different keyboard)
I forgot this part before I asked my question here. After rebooting the last time, - after the reconfiguring, the keyboard didn't work, and therefor I couldn't login :( I fucked it up.
But, is there some OS I should try, that is more user friendly than Ubuntu...?
reboot, select "(single user mode)" from the boot list and enter the reconfiguration here
I'll try that. Thanks.
